definitions.definition: having a smaller distance between opposite sides or surfaces than other similar objects or than normal

examples.text: Cut the vegetables into thin strips.
A number of thin cracks appeared in the wall.
The body was hidden beneath a **thin layer** of soil.
Palm trees cast long, thin shadows on the lawn.
He knew that the ice was too thin to risk crossing the river.
a thin blouse *(= of light cloth)*
a plate of wafer-thin bread and butter
a sliver of rock thin enough to be translucent
She pinched her thin lips together.
The wind blew cold through his thin shirt.
Water forms a thin film between the tyre and the road.

definitions.definition: not covered with much fat or muscle

examples.text: He was tall and thin, with dark hair.
She was looking pale and thin.
How do you stay so thin?
He is as **thin as a rake** *(= very thin)*.
thin legs
How do you manage to stay so thin?
The old horse was painfully thin.

definitions.definition: not growing closely together or in large amounts

examples.text: thin grey hair

definitions.definition: containing more liquid than is normal or expected

examples.text: The sauce was thin and tasteless.
The paint looks a bit thin.

definitions.definition: fairly easy to see through

examples.text: They fought their way through where the smoke was thinner.

definitions.definition: containing less oxygen than normal

examples.text: Humans would not be able to survive in the thin atmosphere of the planet.

definitions.definition: high and weak

examples.text: Her thin voice trailed off into silence.

definitions.definition: not sincere or enthusiastic

examples.text: He gave a thin smile.

definitions.definition: not very bright

examples.text: the thin grey light of dawn

definitions.definition: of poor quality; without an important quality

examples.text: a thin excuse *(= one that people are not likely to believe)*
Their arguments all sound a little thin to me.
The general standard of applicants is pretty thin this year.
His knowledge of the country was somewhat thin.
The evidence seems awfully thin.

definitions.definition: to be taking a risk
to disappear suddenly in a mysterious way

examples.text: She can’t just have vanished into thin air.
At a stroke she could make things vanish into thin air.

definitions.definition: to have many problems or difficulties to deal with; to not be successful

examples.text: He’s had a thin time of it since losing his job.

definitions.definition: from nowhere or nothing, as if by magic

examples.text: Unfortunately, I can’t just conjure up the money out of thin air!

definitions.definition: to try to do so many different things at the same time that you do not do any of them well

examples.text: With four markets to manage, there's a danger that's she's spreading herself too thin.

definitions.definition: if people or things are thick/thin on the ground, there are a lot/not many of them in a place

examples.text: Customers are thin on the ground at this time of year.
Security officers were thick on the ground during the King’s visit.

definitions.definition: an event or action that is the beginning of something more serious and/or unpleasant

examples.text: The introduction of a tax on workplace parking is seen by many as the thin end of the wedge.

definitions.definition: with little or no hair on the head

examples.text: He's starting to get a little thin on top *(= he's losing his hair)*.
He's going bald on top.

definitions.definition: the lack of ability to accept criticism, offensive remarks, etc. without becoming upset

examples.text: You shouldn’t be in politics if you have such a thin skin.

definitions.definition: even when there are problems or difficulties

examples.text: He's supported the team for over ten years through thick and thin.
In marriage, you have to stick together through thick and thin.

definitions.definition: to be in a difficult or dangerous situation where you could easily make a mistake

examples.text: He was walking a fine line between being funny and being rude.
She often seems to tread a thin line between success and failure.
His comedy treads the line between shocking and sickening.
We have to walk a fine line to make sure we don't promote one brand more than another.
His buildings walk the thin line between visionary and completely ridiculous.

definitions.definition: to begin to become weaker or less acceptable

examples.text: These excuses are wearing a little thin *(= because we've heard them so many times before)*.
My patience is beginning to wear very thin.

wordOrigin: Old English thynne, of Germanic origin; related to Dutch dun and German dünn, from an Indo-European root shared by Latin tenuis.
